Description: Fragment of a small seal-impression made of fine brown Nile clay that was hardened after excavation and shows darker discolouration with a partly glossy surface. The rear shows a slightly convex surface like from a leather bag, perpendicular to it two impressions of an unturned cord with a width of 0.2 cm in the break. The front has a small flat area which bends downwards to both lateral sides. On the flat area half of an oval scarab-like seal-impression preserved with finger imprints around it. Visible is a standing animal like a horse (?) with bent head and underneath turned by 180 degrees a crocodile with long tail whose curve follows the outline of the seal. The same motif is found on EA86895, EA86947 and EA86948.
Acquisition notes: Formerly housed by the Birmingham Museum and Art Gallery and the EES London.
